section.title: Conditional sentences with would
section.sectiontitle: We use if + Past simple + would + verb to talk about imaginary, impossible or unlikely situations. We usually use the short form of would.
section.text1a: If I had a ticket, I'd come with you.
section.text2: You don't live in the country.
section.sectiontitle2: We can change the order of the if clause and the main clause. Notice the position of the comma.
section.text3: If I lost my credit card, I'd phone my bank.
section.text3a: I'd phone my bank if I lost my credit card.

section.title: Conditional sentences with would
section.sectiontitle: With the verb be, we can use he/she/it was or were. Were is a little more formal.
section.text1: If my brother were here now, he would know what to do.
section.text1a: If my brother was here now, he'd know what to do.
section.sectiontitle2: In the negative, we use would + not + verb. We usually use the short form.
section.text3a: If he thought it was dangerous, he wouldn't take you.
section.text4a: If I won a lot of money, I wouldn't leave my job.

section.title: Conditional sentences with would
section.sectiontitle: In the question, we use would + subject + verb ...
section.text1a: What would you do if you won the lottery?
section.text2a: Would they ever move to another country? No, they wouldn't.
